pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
See [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Notation.20for.20AntisymmRel/near/485545682).

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ac98bcb416](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19554/commits/ac98bcb41603b6370b49c42192b59d05850aaab8)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ AntisymmRel.ge`
`+ AntisymmRel.le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E2%8B%9B suggests that `x ⋚ y` is closer in meaning to `(Ordering.Compares · x y)`, in that it's used like `±` and `∓` are.

I've only ever seen it used in that context a handful of times ever (and only ever in the context of grading math olympiad exams by pre-university students). I think it's pretty easy to look past that and instead read `⋚` as both `≤` and `≥` at the same time.

Another idea I had was to use either `≤≥` or `≥≤`, though that reads as being much more obviously made up to me.
Some other prior art here is the C++ `x <=> y` operator, which means `compare x y`, and is arguably the ascii version of `⋚`.

I think there's a reason we don't use `<=>` in Lean. In C++ all the comparison operators just return an `int`, and the same is true for `<=>`. In Lean they return a `Prop`, whereas `cmp` returns an `Ordering`. So our convention is more alike [Rust](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/cmp/trait.Ord.html#tymethod.cmp) instead. Maybe that means using the `⋚` symbol causes no ambiguity here?

> In C++ all the comparison operators just return an `int`, and the same is true for `<=>`.

Strictly this isn't true, `<=>` returns a [`std::strong_ordering`](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/compare/strong_ordering) or any number of similar types, depending on the strength of the ordering.
Well, are there any other suggestions? I'm not particularly beholden to `⋚`, I just don't want to write `AntisymmRel (· ≤ ·) a b` over and over.
https://math.stackexchange.com/q/482499/1896 has some similar notation suggestions
Note that comparability isn't the same thing as the antisymmetrization relation. Also note that the symbols `≶` and `⋚` are distinct! Not sure what this all implies.
Just to check `a ≸ b` is problematic for you because it only means the right thing in a preorder?

Actually, `a ≸ b` doesn't mean the right thing except in the very specific case of a preorder whose antisymmetrization is a linear order. Generally, `¬ a < b ∧ ¬ b < a` can also be satisfied when `a` and `b` are incomparable.
My vote is just for no notation. Notation like this is easier on the writer, perhaps, but in my opinion harder on the reader. So just do the work. :-)
I think I could support a `scoped` notation here, but probably @YaelDillies should chime in too.
I personally think it is so niche to write `AntisymmRel` that no notation is okay

> @YaelDillies I personally think it is so niche to write `AntisymmRel` that no notation is okay

Conversely, maybe it's niche precisely because of how hard it is to write? ;)

> @kim-em My vote is just for no notation. Notation like this is easier on the writer, perhaps, but in my opinion harder on the reader. So just do the work. :-)

I don't think `AntisymmRel (. ≤ .) a b` is very friendly on the reader either.

However niche this relation might be in general, I still have to write this at least a few dozen times in order to generalize the `PGame.Equiv` API to other preorders. So even a local notation would be very convenient.

Niels on the Xena Discord suggested `≗` as a notation (read as order equivalent). I like this: it's both a senseless symbol with no risk of ambiguity, but the notation also makes sense. What do you think about making this into a scoped notation?

pullRequest.title: feat: Notation `≤∧≥` for `AntisymmRel (· ≤ ·)`
